DISCUSSION

The current study empirically analyzed the carers’ burden in a sample of carers of people with YOD and LOD. Our analysis highlights that the burden experienced by these carers is related to the different cognitive and clinical status of PwD. Interestingly, none of the carers’ demographic and clinic al characteristics showed a significant relationship with their burden. Several studies have summarized the association between burden and carer’s socio - demographical factors, psychological factors and caring -related factors, for example gender, income, ed ucation level, cultural values, the relationship with the PwD, the amount of informal and formal care available and the carer’s physical and mental status, personality and coping strategies18,34 –37. However, the present study investigated which dementia -specific factors influence carers’ burden. Possibly, the impact of sociodemographic characteristics seems to have been vanished when adverse health conditions were present.

In addition, we expected that there was association between carers’ burden and PwD social and emotional functioning or facial expression recognition ability. Social cognition refers to a variety of cognitive processes that underly social interactions and include the perception of information that is socially relevant (for instance emotio nal facial expressions displayed by

others)38. Impairments in social and emotional functioning or facial expression recognition ability may be more disturbing than the cognitive changes and have been associated with a n increased care rs’ burden39. Nevertheless, the findings of this study indicate that PwD social cognition may not be a factor predominant for the carers’ burden.

A previous study showed evidence of differences in carers’ burden for those caring for people with YOD and LOD18. Unexp ectedly, in the current study there was no significant difference in the carers’ burden between groups. A possible explanation for this lack of difference might be related to the mild burden levels in carers of both groups. Moreover, carers of both groups had moderate resilience levels , a good perception of their quality of life and presented a slight depressive symptom.

It is well -known that people with YOD show faster functional decline than people with LOD40,41. Then it was expected that there would b e a significant difference in the functionality of people with YOD and LOD, but our sample did not present this difference. However, there was a strong trend for a significant difference. Maybe the small sample have influenced the lack of significance. For this reason, in the first regression model, without controlling for NPI and ASPIDD, carers’ burden was related to PwD functionality in both groups. There are controversial results about PwD functional status as an indicator of carers’ burden. Some studies suggest that moderate to severe disability affecting basic daily activities in PwD is related to high carers’ burden42–44. On the other hand, other studies have found weak or no association between PwD functional decline and carers’ burden45–47. Perha ps these discrepancy findings are because carers feel more burdened when dealing with neuropsychiatric symptoms and their unstable nature than cognitive and functional problems48. Therefore, we considered that the understanding of PwD functional decline would be ingenuous as the only predictor of carers’ burden. Moreover, in our sample the association between PwD functional decline and carers’ burden was weak. The PwD functionality could be masking the emergence of others variables. Some studies show that neuropsychiatric symptoms and impairment of awareness of disease of PwD influence the carers’ burden49,50. Therefore, we rand a second regression model controlling for NPI and ASPIDD. The factors that affect the burden of carers of people with YOD differ from those that affect the carers of people with LOD. In the YOD group, the burden was related to PwD global cognition. This result is in line with the statistical difference found in cognition, i.e., people with YOD were more sever ely cognitively impaired than people with LOD. However, there are controversial findings regarding the impact of cognitive functioning on carers’ burden. Etters et al. (2008) reported that the cognitive level of PwD is not a strong predictor of carers’ bur den34. Conversely, the study of Torrisi et al. (2017) found the cognitive

level as a significant predictor of carers’ burden, although less important than the presence of the neuropsychiatric symptoms51. Ismail et al. (2016) showed that the neuropsyc hiatric symptoms in older adults with normal cognition also confer a greater risk of cognitive decline than a sample without this constellation of symptoms52. Therefore, the neuropsychiatric symptoms may function as a mediator between the cognitive decli ne and carers’ burden.

Neuropsychiatric symptoms were a predictor of carers’ burden of people with YOD. The neuropsychiatric symptoms affect nearly all people living with dementia at some point in their disease course and increase as the disease progress53. Apathy is the most persistent and frequent symptom throughout all the stages of dementia. As the disease progresses, delusions, hallucinations, and aggression become more common53. It is important to mention that more than 50% of our sample of people with YOD were in moderate and advanced stages of dementia and showed more neuropsychiatric symptoms compared to people with LOD.

The neuropsychiatric symptoms are challenging for carers and represent some of the main determinants of the increased burden of carers’ people with dementia49. However, carers’ burden was related to PwD awareness of disease in the LOD group. It is worth highlighting that people with LOD presented less neurops ychiatric symptoms. Consequently, the burden was related to impaired awareness or lack of awareness of deficits resulting from the disease. Other studies have found an increase of carers’ burden associated with unawareness50,54,55. Burden involves a subj ective perception related to physical, social, and psychological variables. Carers of people with LOD may take into their observations the PwD awareness to evaluate the deficits as a critical component for their burden. The high prevalence of impaired awar eness negatively affects caregiving activities because the carers have more difficulty in PwD management50.

Strenghs and Limitations This study has several strengths. First, it is one of few studies to empirically compare the carers’ burden of people with YOD and LOD. Second, our study showed that carers of PwD experience a burden that is affected by different factors according to the a ge of onset disease and clinical status of PwD. Overall, our findings provide insights that allow a refined understanding of carers’ burden of people with YOD and LOD and offers essential insights for future research, but this study has several limitations that should be acknowledged. First, we included a small sample, which might have impacted some expected statistical differences. Second, the cross -sectional design does not allow the inference of causal relationships. In addition, there was not a distinct ion between the dementia stages. Some evidence suggests that carers of people with advanced dementia experience the highest levels of burden when
compared with other stages. Finally, we did not investigate the support received by carers as studies have sho wn that both formal and informal support may reduce the burden.

CONCLUSION Our study shows that although carers’ burden was similar between YOD and LOD groups, more cognitive impairment and more neuropsychiatric symptoms of PwD corroborated carers’ burden in the YOD group but not in the LOD group. The PwD unawareness of disease was an indicative of carers’ burden in the LOD group. Clinically, our study demonstrates that caregiving is not a homogenous task. Caring for a person with YOD is not the same as ca ring for a person with LOD. The challenges are different as they include different biological, psychological, and social backgrounds related to the age of onset. Also, our findings reinforce that burden is a complex and multidimensional concept. These poin ts need to be reflected in the development of targeted social support systems and policies addressed to each group of carers.

Este artigo apresenta um estudo longitudinal que investigou o impacto da COVID -19 na sobrecarga e qualidade de vida de cuidadores de pessoas com Doença de Alzheimer. As avaliações aconteceram antes e durante a pandemia.

The impact of COVID -19 on burden and quality of life of carers of people with Alzheimer’s Disease: A longitudinal study

ABSTRACT Background: The COVID -19 pandemic affects all people; however, this context increased the need for care for people with Alzheimer’s Disease (PwAD) due to higher mortality among this population. One of the measures to contain the virus was social isolation and home confinement, then some treatments and services were disrupted and t he families had to face the care for PwAD without help. Thereby, the hours of caregiving were grown. These aspects may negatively affect the carers’ mental health.
Objective: To compare the impact of PwAD cognitive functioning, functionality and neuropsych iatric symptoms on carers’ quality of life and burden before and during the pandemic.

Method: The study had a longitudinal design. The sample was composed of 46 dyads of carer and PwAD. The first evaluation (2019) was made by personal interview, whereas th e second (2020 -2021) was made by video -calling .

Result: Carers' burden was related to their schooling and quality of life, and PwAD delusions at baseline. At follow -up, carers’ burden was related to PwAD hallucination and agitation and carers' quality of l ife. The carers’ quality of life was related to PwAD cognition and apathy and carers' burden at baseline. At follow -up, the PwAD disinhibition and carers’ burden were related to quality of life.

Conclusion: In both moments of evaluation, carers’ quality of life was determined by their burden. The PwD cognitive functioning and the presence of neuropsychiatric symptoms impacted carers’ burden and quality of life. Clinically, our findings provide insights to offer services that could mitigate the harmful conse quences of social isolation. Keywords: dementia; carer; burden; quality of life; COVID -19.
INTRODUCTION

Dementia is characterized by progressive impairment of memory and other cognitive functions that affect the individual's performance in social and professional activities (American Psychiatric Association, 2014) , being most common in older people (Lopes & Bottino, 2002) . Among dementia syndromes, the most prevalent is Alzheimer's disease (Herrera Jr et al., 2002; Lopes & Bottino, 2002) . The progressive decline of cognitive functions impacts the person's functional capacity, including basic acti vities of daily living, such as bathing, dressing and eating, and instrumental activities of daily living, such as administering medication, paying bills and housework (Fagundes et al., 2017) . Given the wide range of deficits, people with dementia (PwD) commonly need care. Thus, emerges the figure of the informal carer (i.e., family members, friends, neighbors, or volunteers), the one who becomes responsible for the entire care routine.

According to Wimo (2018) , about 84% of older adults with dementia live at home. Caring for PwD needs an invested effort due to the complex symptoms exhibited by the PwD (Livingston et al., 2020) . Furthermore, independent of dementia stage, PwD commonly showed behavioral and psychological disturbances (Scaricamazza et a l., 2019) . These symptoms are the most causes for carers’ burden and include psychosis, hyperactivity, affective symptoms, euphoria, apathy, disinhibition, motor disturbances, night -time behaviors, and eating disturbances (Bessey & Walaszek, 2019; van de r Linde et al., 2014) .

The challenge of providing care affects carers’ quality of life, defined as “individual perception of the position of their life considering the cultural values of the place where they live, in addition to their goals, expectation s, standards and concerns” (WHOQOL Group, 1996) . The concept goes beyond the presence or absence of illness. The quality of life is interrelated with “physical health, psychological state, level of independence, social relationships, environmental factor s and personal beliefs” (WHOQOL Group, 1996) . The carers’ quality of life is strongly related to carers’ burden and depressive symptoms (Santos et al., 2014) . Dementia has a considerable human, material and emotional cost. The carers’ burden is increased due to the workload spent on care, the lack of information and support, the degree of tiredness and the activities performed in daily life (Novelli et al., 2010a) that, in turn, lead to worsening quality of life. Carers’ burden is a complex multidimensional construct composed of aspects inherent to the carer – such as their personal psychological well -being – but also of carers’ unrelated factors and depending on the PwD specific symptoms as well as the

availability of external support (Vitaliano et al., 1991) . Therefore, sometimes the care process negatively influences the physical and mental health of these carers (Novelli et al., 2010a) . In March 2020, with COVID -19 multiplying in several countries, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared that the world had reached a pandemic level. The COVID -19 pandemic affects all people, but higher mortality is expected among older adults and people with chronic medical condition (Bhidayasir i et al., 2020) . Hence, the pandemic increased the need for care for PwD. Given this scenario, the role of the carer is of utmost importance to protect PwD from infection, besides the daily care (Dourado et al., 2020) .

One of the measures to contain t he virus was social isolation and home confinement; therefore, some treatments and services focused on PwD, such as day care centers, were disrupted by the pandemic (Cuffaro et al., 2020) . Then, the families had to face the care for PwD without help. In addition, the contact between PwD with their carers and the hours of caregiving was grown, an aspect that may negatively affect the mental health of carers (Kimura Recent studies reported that the social isolation may impair PwD, especiall y on behavioral and neuropsychiatric symptoms. For example, an Italian multicenter study reported an increase of neuropsychiatric symptoms in approximately 60% of PwD (Cagnin et al., 2020) . The same study showed that neuropsychiatric symptoms are the mos t important aspects reducing the quality of life for both PwD and carers (Cagnin et al., 2020) .

Further research realized in Italy (Altieri & Santangelo, 2021; Mazzi et al., 2020; Zucca et al., 2021) , Greece (Tsapanou et al., 2021) , Portugal (Borges -Machado et al., 2020) , Argentina (Cohen et al., 2020) and India (Vaitheswaran et al., 2020) has demonstrated that the pandemic produced negative psychological consequences in carers of PwD (Mazzi et al., 2020; Vaitheswaran et al., 2020) as an increase of levels of depression (Altieri & Santangelo, 2021) , anxiety (Cohen et al., 2020) , and burden (Borges -Machado et al., 2020; Tsapanou et al., 2021; Zucca et al., 2021) . During the pandemic, many carers experienced the lack of a break from daily care in a context in which PwD presented worsening cognition and functionality. Furthermore, an overload of tasks may easily impair carers' ability to cope with an increase of a PwD demand, and as a consequence, has an increase in psych ological distress and decrease of quality of life (Borelli et al., 2021) . This point requires attention because, before the pandemic, carers of PwD already had an increased risk of mortality (Schulz & Beach, 1999) . There is scarce evidence about how ca rers’ mental health has been affected during the pandemic. Even so, the current literature substantiates the hypothesis of poorer quality of life and higher burden in carers of PwD during the pandemic (Borelli et al., 2021; Messina et al.,

2022; Rainero et al., 2021; Zucca et al., 2021) . Thus, this study aimed to compare how PwD’s cognitive functioning, functionality and neuropsychiatric functions impact family carers’ quality of life and burden before and during the pandemic.
METHOD Study Design The study had a longitudinal design.

Participants The sample was composed of 46 dyads of people with Alzheimer’s disease and their carers seen at the Center for Alzheimer's Disease (CDA) outpatient clinic of the Institute of Psychiatry of Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro.

We included people with mild to severe dementia according to Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) (Maia et al., 2006) and Mini -Mental State Examination (MMSE) (Bertolucci et al., 1994) scores of 9 to 26. The clinical diagnosis of Alzheime r’s disease was made by a psychiatrist centered on clinical interviews with the PwD and his or her carer, cognitive screening tests, laboratory tests, and imaging methods. All diagnoses met the criteria for Alzheimer’s disease according to the Diagnostic a nd Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM -V) (American Psychiatric Association, 2014) . Only carers identified as primary carer (i.e., family members, friends, neighbors or volunteers) were included in the study. The carers should be able to provide detailed information about the PwD. Dyads were excluded from the study for any history of psychiatric disorders (i.e., bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, major depression), head trauma, alcohol abuse, or epilepsy in the PwD.

This study was approved by the ethics committee of the Institute of Psychiatry of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro. All PwD and their carers signed informed consent forms prior to the assessment.

Procedures The evaluation was administered to PwD a nd carers separately at baseline (2019) and 12 months (2020 -2021). Due to the social isolation caused by COVID -19, we had to modify our study protocols to continue collecting data. So, we used electronic informed consent and online questionnaires and tests .

PwD had their cognition assessed. The carers provided information about the PwD, including demographics, dementia severity, neuropsychiatric symptoms and the ability to perform activities of daily living. Moreover, the carers' quality of life and burden were assessed. A trained psychologist presented the instruments in the same order for all participants. The first evaluation (2019) was made by personal interview, whereas the second (2020 -2021) was made remotely by a phone with acess to internet . Before the evaluation, the carer s were contacted via telephone and instructed to use a video -calling applica tion at moment of evaluation and to stay in a calm and quiet environment to answer the questionnaries uninterruptedly . In terms of PwD evaluation, the carers were instructed to accompany the PwD during the assessment that was made video -calling too .
Assessments and Measures Sociodemographic data for PwD and carers were gathered using a structured questionnaire. We used the Brazilian adaptation of all cognitive and clinical instruments.

PwD Measures Cognition The Mini -Mental Status Examination (MMSE) is an instrument comprised of 30 items that assess orientation, l earning, short -term memory, language, comprehension and basic motor skills. The total score ranges from 0 to 30, with a lower score indicating more impaired cognition (Bertolucci et al., 1994) .

Severity of dementia The Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) was utilized to measure dementia severity. This scale is comprised of six cognitive and functional domains: memory, orientation, judgment and problem solving, community affairs, home and hobbies, and personal care. CDR has a categorical scoring of 0 (no demen tia), 0.5 (questionable dementia), 1 (mild dementia), 2 (moderate dementia) and 3 (severe dementia) (Maia et al., 2006) .

Functionality The Pfeffer Functional Activities Questionnaire (FAQ) comprises 10 items regarding functional abilities. Each item has ratings that range from normal (0) to dependent (3), with a total of 30 points. Higher scores indicate greater functional impairment (Dutra et al., 2015) .

Neuropsychiatric Symptoms The 12 -item Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) was applied to assess delu sions, hallucinations, agitation, apathy, anxiety, depression, euphoria, irritability, disinhibition, aberrant motor behavior, change in appetite, and nighttime behavior disturbances. The total score ranges from 0 to 144. The NPI total score is the sum of frequency versus severity ratings for all domains. Higher scores indicate greater levels of neuropsychiatric symptoms (Camozzato et al., 2015) .

Carer measures Quality of life The Quality of Life in Alzheimer’s Disease (QoL -AD) is comprised of 13 domains (physical health, energy, mood, living situation, memory, family, marriage, friends, you as a whole, ability to do chores, ability to do things for fun, money and life as a whol e) that are rated as poor (1), fair (2), good (3), or excellent (4). We use the carer’s QoL version (C -QoL). The total score ranges from 13 to 52. Higher scores indicate better quality of life (Novelli et al.,

Burden The Zarit Burden Interview (ZBI) comprises 22 items that measure the impact of caring for PwD on the carer’s life. Scores range from 0 to 88. Higher scores indicate a higher level of burden (Scazufca, 2002) .

Statistical Analysis We used the SPSS software for Win dows version 22.0 for all statistical analyses. Before analysis, the variables were inspected for normality. The descriptive analyses of all variables were performed according to the type of variable studied. All analyses were carried out by thematic block s, namely: sociodemographic data of the PwD and carers; clinical data of PwD and carers. The Chi -square and Paired Samples T -Test were used to compare the baseline and follow -up measures. We used Cohen’s d to measure the effect size of the significant diff erences in the clinical variables between baseline and follow -up. The values indicated small (< 0.5), moderate (0.5 –0.8), or large (> 0.8) effects.

Matrices of correlations were created to investigate the relation of all variables with the burden and quali ty of life at baseline and 12 months. Strong (positive or negative) correlations were defined as 0.71 to 0.9, moderate correlations as 0.31 to 0.70, and weak correlations as 0.1

to 0.30. Multivariate linear regressions were performed to determine the facto rs related to carers’ burden and quality of life in both moments. The best models were selected on the basis of a trade -off between the highest explained variance (R2) and highest cross -validity (adjusted R2). For all analyses, the α -level was set at p ≤ 0 .05.

DISCUSSION

In this study, we longitudinally investigated the factors related to the burden and quality of life of carers of PwD before and during the pandemic and examined how the pandemic context could influence the differences.

Our findings suggest a lack of signi ficant difference in carers’ quality of life and burden between baseline and follow -up. This result may be influenced by the assistance to care received for 67% of carers. We may suppose that other family members spent more time at

home during the social i solation period. Therefore, the presence of housemates reduced the risk of depression and conflicts, thus indicating that carers’ burden may be mitigated (Bressan et al., 2020) . Also, higher support for carers of PwD has been associated with a better qua lity of life (Farina et al., 2017) .

We also found a decline in PwD cognition and more impaired functionality with moderate effect size, respectively, besides worsening of dementia severity. This finding is in line with a larger study realized in Italy – the first epicenter of COVID -19 pandemic outside China – where 55.1% of PwD presented an impaired in cognitive funct ions (Rainero et al., 2021) . Another study found that most PwD showed cognitive decline and worsening in the activities of daily living (Cohen et al., 2020) . The social isolation and home confinement resulting from quarantine caused a sudden interrupti on of PwD routine such as social interaction and cognitive stimulation, which may explain the worsening of their cognition and functionality (Borelli et al., 2021; Rainero et al., 2021) . The social isolation impaired the non - pharmacological support, such as daycare centers (Borelli et al., 2021) . The daycare centers have been considered an important health technology in the configuration of support strategies for PwD and their carers through interventions that promote health, prevent and treat, improve rehabilitation and long -term care (Maffioletti et al., 2019) . Clinically, the decline in cognitive functioning and more impaired functionality highlight the need to develop at -home interventions to alleviate the impact of the decreased stimulation.

Moreo ver, there was a decrease in PwD anxious symptoms with a moderate effect size. A study performed by Moretti, Caruso, Giuffré and Tiribelli (2021) , demonstred that s ocial isolation might cause the feeling of loneliness, which can exacerbate behavior alterations . However, in our sample, the PwD did not reside alone and during the quarantine 80,4% of carers were isolated , in the others words the carers were at home. T here was an approximation between PwD and carer that may contribuated with the decrease in PwD anxious symptoms. Carers’ Burden At baseline, we found a relationship between carers’ burden and PwD schooling. Some studies showed that low education levels of PwD were associated with higher carers’burden (Abdollahpour et al., 2012; Agüera -Ortiz et al., 2010) . Interestingly, our study indicated the opposite effect, namely higher schooling of PwD was associated with increased carers’ burden. Also, the study performed by Rosas -Carrasco et al. (2014) found the same res ult. PwD with higher schooling may present a higher capacity to argue or question the carer and the care paid or refuse to take medication and these behaviors may increase the carers’ burden (Rosas‐ Carrasco et al., 2014) .

We also found a relation between different neuropsychiatric symptoms and carers’ burden in both moments. The PwD delusions were related to carers’ burden at baseline. The association between burden and PwD delusions is well -known and shown in others studies (Huang et al., 2012; Kaufer et al., 1998; Matsumoto et al., 2007) . Therefore, the delusions in the PwD tend to be very distressing to the carer, as they are symptoms that are not readily distracted (Cheng, 2017) .

We found that carer’s burden was related to PwD hallucination and agi tation/ aggression at follow -up. There was an increase in these symptoms over time. In a review of literature realized by Simonetti et al. (2020) , agitation is one of the most frequent neuropsychiatric symptoms during the COVID -19 pandemic triggered by l ong isolation. Another study reported that aggravation of neuropsychiatric symptoms, like hallucination, was observed in 51.9% of PwD (Rainero et al., 2021) . The literature points out that neuropsychiatric symptoms are usual in dementia (Ballard & Corbet t, 2010; Kales et al., 2019) and the COVID -19 lockdown seem is associated with aggravation of several neuropsychiatric symptoms. Although most neuropsychiatric symptoms did not present a significant difference when we compared longitudinally, some neurop sychiatric symptoms showed a decrease over time. In line with our findings, the study conducted by Cravello et al. (2021) did not find significant changes in the mean NPI scores before and after the COVID -19 lockdown and the NPI score was also lower after lockdown than before. We may suppose that our PwD sample had low levels of neuropsychiatric symptoms because they were selected in a treatment center for Alzheimer’s Disease. Despite the suspension of face -to-face service during the most critical period of the pandemic, some PwD were treated remotely. Moreover, these findings may be explained by carers’ adjustment to the caregiving tasks over time enabling the carers to have another perception about neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Carers’ quality of life When we analyzed the factors related to carers’ quality of life, we also found the impact of the neuropsychiatric symptoms. At baseline, PwD apathy was related to the carer’s quality of life. Apathy is the most common neuropsychiatric symp tom in people with Alzheimer’s disease, defined as diminished will and initiative, lack of interest in activities (Nobis & Husain, 2018) . The apathy may be frustrating when it appears that the PwD is capable of doing a task but simply does not do it or w ill only do so if the carer uses strong exhortation. PwD cognition was related to carers’ quality of life at baseline. However, according to a review of Farina et al. (2017) , most of the literature finds no association between carers’ quality of life an d severity of cognitive impairment. Hence, perhaps, our finding is influenced

by the increase of caring demands resulting from worsening cognition of PwD. In addition, at follow -up, carers’ quality of life was related to the disinhibition of PwD. Disinhibi tion is linked to frontal systems behavioral functioning and seems to be more challenging to manage and more burdensome to carers than the more passive behaviors (Davis & Tremont, 2007) . In both moments of evaluation, carers’ quality of life was determined by their burden. The reverse was also true; carers’ burden was inversely related to their quality of life at baseline and follow -up. In line with previous evidence, carers with higher levels of burden report lower levels of quality of life (Contador et al., 2012) . All the changes imposed by the pandemic seem to have affected the carers’ mental health in multiple ways. Thus, carers had their quality of life decreased over time. It may be considered that some carers are thems elves in risk groups to contracting COVID -19. Many are older adults who may not manage their own needs with caring responsibilities (Alzheimer Europe, 2020) .

The present study is not free from limitations. We included a small sample, which might have im pacted some expected statistical differences. The lack of data on carers' depressive symptoms and coping strategies limits causal inference and possibly underestimates the negative impact of the social isolation period. Furthermore, the first evaluation wa s made by personal interview, whereas the second was made by video -calling , which could be a risk of bias. In addition, we did not concentrate our evaluation in the same wave or pandemic period which may be a potential limitation of analyses.

Clinically, our findings provide insights that allow a more understanding of the burden and quality of life of carers’ during the COVID -19 pandemic. Furthermore, the present study includes a longitudinal evaluation with the same tests performed before and during the pandemic to demonstrate how different factors will be related with carers’ mental health depending on care context.

The major finding of this study was the quality of provided caregiving during the pandemic . The PwD did not show increase in neur opsychiatric symptoms and these may be related with the carers’ support. The original data about the clinical characteristics of carers of PwD, before and during the pandemic, that should be considered to offer services that could mitigate the harmful cons equences of social isolation.

10 DISCUSSÃO

Esta tese apresentou as análises de dois estudos transversais e um estudo longitudinal sobre cuidadores de pessoas com DA. Para investigar a nossa hipótese transversal de que os cuidadores de pessoas com DA de início precoce apresentam maior sobrecarga e menor resiliência quando comparados com cuidadores de pessoas com DA de início tardio, nos baseamos nos seguintes objetivos: comparar a resiliência e sobrecarga dos dois grupos de cuidadores e analisar os fatores relacionados a esses aspectos clínicos dos cuidadores. Com relação à nossa hipótese longitudinal de que os cuidadores apresentam pior qualidade de vida e maior sobrecarga durante a pandemia, nosso objetivo específico foi investigar como o funcionamento cognitivo, a funcionalidade e os sintomas neu ropsiquiátricos das pessoas com DA impactam a qualidade de vida e a sobrecarga dos cuidadores familiares antes e durante a pandemia de COVID -19.

O primeiro estudo comparou a resiliência dos cuidadores. Apesar da nossa hipótese inicial sobre a diferença na resiliência dos cuidadores ter sido refutada, quando avaliamos quais fatores estão relacionados à resiliência do cuidador de acordo com a idade de início da doença do paciente, vimos que há diferenças importantes entre os cuidadores. A resiliência foi inversamente relacionada aos sintomas depressivos dos cuidadores de ambos os grupos. No grupo de cuidadores de pessoas com demência de início tardio outros fatores como a escolaridade dos cuidadores, o tempo de doença e os sintomas depressivos do paciente for am relacionados à resiliência desses cuidadores. A resiliência pode ser influenciada pelo contexto do cuidado, pelo estado clínico do paciente e pelos recursos individuais dos cuidadores (GAUGLER; KANE; NEWCOMER, 2007) . Nossos achados demonstraram a inte ração entre essa constelação de aspectos na resiliência dos cuidadores de pessoas com demência de início tardio. Por outro lado, a resiliência parece ser afetada apenas pela saúde mental dos cuidadores de pessoas com demência de início precoce. Este estudo foi o primeiro a investigar fatores relacionados à resiliência de cuidadores de pessoas com demência de início precoce comparados a cuidadores de pessoas com demência de início tardio e concluímos que a resiliência dos cuidadores deve ser entendida como t endo características particulares que variam de acordo com os grupos de cuidadores.

Apesar de ser importante reconhecer os fatores associados à capacidade de adaptação positiva de um cuidador é igualmente importante ter uma compreensão dos efeitos negativo s do cuidar. No segundo estudo comparamos a sobrecarga dos cuidadores, mas não houve

diferença significativa na sobrecarga. Também nesse estudo nós investigamos quais sintomas clínicos dos pacientes poderiam estar associados à sobrecarga dos cuidadores em ambos os grupos para tanto, na análise de regressão linear, nós controlamos as variáveis referentes à consciência da doença e aos sintomas neuropsiquiátricos dos pacientes. Os aspectos clínicos dos pacientes associados a sobrecarga dos cuidadores de pessoa s com demência de início precoce foram a cognição global e os sintomas neuropsiquiátricos. No grupo de demência de início tardio, a consciência da doença foi o único aspecto clínico associado à sobrecarga dos cuidadores. Nosso estudo mostrou que os cuidado res vivenciam uma sobrecarga que é afetada por diferentes fatores de acordo com a idade de início da doença e o estado clínico do paciente. Embora a sobrecarga dos cuidadores tenha sido semelhante entre os grupos, mais comprometimento cognitivo e mais sint omas neuropsiquiátricos dos pacientes corroboram a sobrecarga dos cuidadores no grupo de demência de início precoce, mas não no grupo de demência de início tardio. A falta de consciência da doença dos pacientes foi um indicativo da sobrecarga dos cuidadore s, no grupo de demência de início tardio.

Um aspecto importante relacionado a saúde dos cuidadores é a presença de sintomas depressivos. A presença de sintomas depressivos implica no agravamento da qualidade de vida e saúde física, prejuízo na capacidade de realizar atividades de vida diária e maiores taxas de morbidade e mortalidade (ROCHA; FLECK, 2010) . De acordo com a literatura, c uidadores de pessoas com DA têm mais ansiedade e depressão do que não cuidadores (COOPER; BALAMURALI; LIVINGSTON, 2007; MOISE; SCHWARZINGER; UM, 2004) .

Em estudo anterior , nossos achados indicaram que cuidadores de pessoas com DA de início precoce apresenta m maiores níveis de sintomas depressivos do que cuidadores de pessoas com DA de início tardio (KIMURA et al., 2020) . Embora nesta tese não tenhamos desenvolvido um novo estudo sobre a comparação dos sintomas depressivos dos cuidadores de ambos os grupos, nos dois estudos comparativos esses sintomas foram avaliados. Não encontramos diferença significativa na comparação dos sintomas depressivos, mas os cuidadores de pessoas com demência de início precoce apresentaram um nível levemente maior de sintomas depressivos. Tendo em vista que sintomas de depressão nos cuidadores estão fortemente associados à presença de sintomas neuropsiquiátricos nos pacientes (COOPER; BALAMURALI; LIVINGSTON, 2007; FARINA et al., 2017) , consideramos como perspectiva futura um estudo dos sintomas depressivos dos cuidadores que tenha como objetivo investigar como o funcionamento cognitivo, a funcionalidade e os sintomas neuropsiquiátricos das pessoas com demência impacta nos sintomas depressivos dos cuidadores de ambos os grup os.

A partir dos achados dos dois estudos comparativos realizados podemos observar que existem diferenças nos fatores que influenciam a resiliência e a sobrecarga dos dois grupos de cuidadores de acordo com a idade de início da doença do paciente. Poucas p esquisas reconhecem a heterogeneidade de características existentes entre os cuidadores, considerando este grupo como um único bloco. Muitos estudos mesclam cuidadores de pessoas com demência sem levar em consideração a idade de início da doença do pacient e e não avaliam as consequências comportamentais, psicológicas e do estado cognitivo e funcional causad as pela doença de acordo com a idade de início. Poucos estudos transversais comparam empiricamente os dois grupos de cuidadores e os estudos longitudinai s são escassos. A presente tese se propôs a destacar as diferenças entre os cuidadores com o intuito de fornecer um conhecimento aprofundado dos aspectos clínicos e psicossociais de cada grupo.

No último estudo longitudinal, investigamos a qualidade de vid a e a sobrecarga em uma amostra de 46 díades de cuidadores -pacientes. O momento 1 foi antes da pandemia de COVID - 19 e o momento 2 durante. Encontramos um declínio na cognição e prejuízo na funcionalidade, juntamente com um agravamento da gravidade da doenç a devido à pandemia de COVID -19.

Por isso, pressupúnhamos que haveria uma diferença tanto na qualidade de vida quanto na sobrecarga dos cuidadores nas comparações do primeiro com o segundo momento, porém isso não se confirm ou nas análises dos dados. A falta de diferença na sobrecarga e qualidade d e vida dos cuidadores, provavelmente foi causada pela amostra pequena deste estudo.

No momento 1, a sobrecarga dos cuidadores estava relacionada ao seu nível de escolaridade e qualidade de vida, e delírios dos pacientes. Já a qualidade de vida foi relacio nada à cognição e apatia dos pacientes e à sobrecarga dos cuidadores. No momento 2, a sobrecarga dos cuidadores estava relacionada à alucinação e agitação/agressão dos pacientes e qualidade de vida dos cuidadores. Enquanto que a qualidade de vida dos cuida dores estava relacionada a desinibição dos pacientes e a sobrecarga dos cuidadores. Ou seja, os fatores relacionados à sobrecarga e qualidade de vida dos cuidadores não são os mesmos antes e durante a pandemia. No entanto, em ambos os momentos de avaliação , a qualidade de vida dos cuidadores foi relacionada a pela sua sobrecarga e vice -versa mostrando que essa influência está para além do contexto de pandemia. Nossos achados apontam que todas as mudanças impostas pela pandemia somadas à piora do estado do p aciente afetam a saúde mental dos cuidadores.
10.1 LIMITAÇÕES DOS ESTUDOS Nossos estudos tem algumas limitações que precisam ser mencionadas. Os estudos possuem uma amostra relativamente pequena e de conveniência. Os dois estudos de

comparação, além de s erem transversais, incluíram pessoas com outras demências além da Doença de Alzheimer. No estudo de comparação da resiliência não avaliamos os traços de personalidade dos cuidadores. Esses fatores podem afetar a resiliência dos cuidadores de ambos os grupo s. No estudo de comparação da sobrecarga não foi realizada uma análise com base na distinção entre os estágios da demência. Algumas evidências sugerem que os cuidadores de pessoas com demência avançada experimentam os níveis mais altos de sobrecarga quando comparados com outros estágios. Também não investigamos o apoio recebido pelos cuidadores, pois estudos mostraram que tanto o apoio formal quanto o informal podem reduzir a sobrecarga. No estudo longitudinal, a falta de dados sobre sintomas depressivos e estratégias de enfrentamento dos cuidadores limita a inferência causal e possivelmente subestima o impacto negativo do período de isolamento social. Além disso, a primeira avaliação foi feita por entrevista pessoal, enquanto a segunda foi feita por telefon e, o que pode ser um viés. Também, não concentramos nossa avaliação no mesmo período de onda da pandemia, o que pode ser uma limitação para as análises.
11 CONCLUSÃO

O Brasil, país em desenvolvimento, possui uma rede de cuidado direcionada a pessoas com DA e seus cuidadores ainda incipiente . O aumento da incidência da DA na população brasileira, com poucos recursos formais, acaba propiciando um cenário em que os cuidadores têm que lidar com os sintomas da doença muitas vezes sem o conhecimento e apoio adequados. Ao longo dos anos de estudo iniciados no Mestrado, foi possível perceber que os cuidadores enfrentam problemas psicológicos/emocionais, físicos, financeiros e sociais subsequentes à tarefa de cuidar. O cuidador na medida em que vivenci a situações de sobrecarga, estará exposto à possibilidade de adoecimento e, consequentemente, irá necessitar do suporte dos serviços e profissionais de saúde.

Clinicamente, nossas descobertas fornecem insights sobre aspectos clínicos relacionados aos cuid adores. Cuidar de uma pessoa com DA de início precoce não é o mesmo que cuidar de uma pessoa com DA de início tardio. Os desafios são diferentes, pois incluem diferentes fatores clínicos, psicológic os e sociais relacionadas à idade de início. A compreensão desses aspectos é fundamental para o desenvolvimento de estratégias de intervenção mais adequadas às demandas dos cuidadores de cada grupo.

Além disso, nossos achados mostraram dados originais sobre as características clínicas tanto de cuidadores quanto de pacientes, antes e durante a pandemia, que devem ser considerados para oferecer serviços que possam mitigar as consequências danosas do isolamento social.

Com base nos estudos realizados previamente nos dois anos de Mestrado e, atualmente, nos quatro an os de Doutorado, conclui -se que cada vez mais é proeminente a necessidade de maior apoio aos cuidadores através de serviços e políticas que auxili em os cuidadores a permanecer na função por mais tempo, a melhorar a qualidade dos cuidados que prestam, a enfrentar as consequências negativas da prestação de cuidados, a aumentar os níveis de resiliência e isso melhorar a sua própria qualidade de vida.
